content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Everything is fine

The stub generator is not correct, since it's creating a string of length 50. There're cases that would not fit on this (e.g. Bigger Sequence has 114 characters). Also, I think it would be better to read the sequence as multiple integers instead of a string.
Maybe passing the number of elements of the sequence first would make it easier to read the input in some languages.

Otherwise, nice problem! I think it would make more sense to use the maximum value of each pair instead of using always the number on the left, but that's not a big deal.

I test it in IDE and it said that "xCount is not defined".
 You need in the beginning before the loop to put value in  xCount.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: les inputs sont incorrect
Looks fine. Only surprise was not recognizing during the first read that the last number is essentially ignored (no trailing points). But still fairly quick to solve.

Goal: "space the two numbers of a sequence" suggests there will be exactly 2 numbers in the sequence.
Suggestion: "The goal is to reformat a sequence of integers, so that each pair is separated by a number of points ('.') equal to the number on the left."

Input: typo: integeers -> integers

Output: "with the good amount of point" doesn't make sense
Suggestion: "A string containing the sequence of integers, T, separated by the correct number of '.'s"

Constraints: Suggestion: add a limit for the number of integers: "1 <= len(T) <= 20"

Tests/Validators: Each validator should check the same case as the corresponding test
Example: 0 is a special case (I can imagine some solutions failing only when the input is 0), so when a test includes a 0 input, the validator should include a 0 input.

IMO, Test 3 (Input: 00000) is unfair:
- You don't mention input with leading 0s anywhere in the statement
- The default code converts '00000' to 0
More importantly, this is the only input with leading 0s. Code which gives the output '0' for test 3 (fail) can still pass all the validators.

Validator 4: The input contains a double space

Fixed typo: integeers -> integers

I think the goal is clear enough. And if you don't understand directly, you will understand with a short look on the first Testcase.

You could also give a constraint for the number of integers in the sequence.

"The numbers of the sequence are between 0 and 500" -> looking at the testcase 3 and 4, it would be better to write inclusive 500 and inclusive 0.
oh thanks, I had forgotten the spaces for test 3
peux tu me donner plus de precisions afin que je puisse me corriger ?
